author: Special Correspondent
text:
Post floods, Chennai sees more people volunteering to clean up lakes

Following the floods, there has been an increased awareness about protecting and maintaining waterbodies.

Environmentalist Foundation of India (EFI), a voluntary organisation, which is engaged in the conservation of waterbodies, has seen a spurt in the number of people signing up for volunteering opportunities with it, after the floods.

Malini Hari, one of the volunteers with EFI, said several residents’ welfare associations were coming forward to join hands with the organisation to clean up waterbodies.

On Saturday, several volunteers came together to clear the vegetation in the Adambakkam lake.

Kittu Park pond

EFI founder Arun Krishnamurthy said, “We are planning to clean up Kittu Park pond in West Mambalam on Sunday along with support of the residents’ welfare association there. Volunteering to restore a waterbody means a lot of hard work and it is good that more people are taking up volunteering work that involves lake clean-up. This time, it’s not just individuals but also residents welfare associations.”

The Foundation has identified 16 lakes in and around the city that it wants to rejuvenate under the aegis of water security mission launched by the Municipal Administration and Water Supply Department.

The organisation is now focussing on waterbodies on the western fringes of the city too, he said.

“We plan to clean up the Thiruverkadu lake and Vilingiyambakkam near Poonamallee soon,” he said.

He said that the Foundation had now moved to the next level: besides cleaning up lakes, it is also taking steps to improve waterbodies as ecological habitats.
